This same argument of "he isnt a person" has strong eccos to a "no true scotsman" fallacy, and, given the knowledge that Im no authority, it sure seems textbook to me. Again, thats fallacy. For those of you who(m?) may not know, the "no true scotsman" fallacy is one of several notably flawed arguments including ad hominem fallacies, strawman fallacies, red herrings, etc. The "no true scots man" fallacy works by taking an action done by a member of a group (whether the member be one person or a collection of people) and saying that "any true member of [insert group here] wouldnt do [insert action here]." This is a fallacy, one notable enough to usually be one of the first five fallacies that someone may learn. It is literally famous for being wrong and has been wrong so often and for so long that it has its own name that has been adopted into the vocabulary of many laypersons (like myself), yet despite this it is so commonly allowed to slip by. Arguments about "Islamic terror" come to mind: whether you like it or not, they identify as muslim and are therefore given a platform to practice their beliefs in certain muslim communities--at this point I would like to add that I hold no purposeful bias against any muslim I am simply pointing out that saying that they arent muslim because muslims wouldnt do that is wrong. E3: ‰ÛÏPeer review‰Û is an important aspect of the scientific method. Any scientific claim should face basic scrutiny from other experts in the field in order to weed out clearly invalid or unscientific arguments. But peer review is also open to some obvious abuses. An entrenched scientific establishment can use peer review to close ranks against a radical new idea, regardless of its scientific merit. By the same token, an establishment can conspire to grease the wheels for fellow members of the clique, ensuring that they get their articles published in prestigious journals while others don‰Ûªt.

We are all humans. -Look Ameer, there was almost 63 million American citizens who voted for Trump last year. They are NOT all racists and bigots, some are just people who are concerned about the role of the government in their lives and the direction this country is heading. This is one of the largest problems with the media today, you can pick or choose your own stories; the ones that you agree with. When we do this we only see OUR side, the "right" side. If one only looks at one side of the population, questions like yours start to arise. Instead of understanding the arguments of the other side and their legitimate concerns and worries, we push them away. We divide ourselves into Democrats and Republicans, saying the other side is evil, stupid, racist, communist. What we need to do is to reach across and realize the "others" are just people, not the enemy. We are Americans, not Republicans and Democrats. I need, we need, this country needs to be able to communicate our grievances WITHOUT attacking those who disagree with us. I am a Republican, and am hopeful for Trumps presidency, while still maintaining doubts about some of the directions he is taking. E2: I do find it amusing how an agreement can be interpreted in two opposing ways so easily. The agreement has the US frontloading the costs while it has China and India only changing policies post 2030. Pruitt considers this to be a bad deal for America, but MSNBC says it is a good deal for America. Clearly they are using two different measurements as how you interpret what is good for America. I think Pruitts correct and here is why. If you are measuring economic opportunity, then paying up front will obviously hurt more than if you delay any action for 13 years. So economically speaking Pruitt is correct. The other way to measure is through carbon emissions. In this case the Americans would "win". But winning is relative of course. Americans lower their emissions, but China and India have blown away any American savings so the savings at a global level are changed only very minimally. The only victory is a moral one. As for the fact that Americans are lowering emissions, that is mostly due to the switch from coal to natural gas and has very little to do with green policies which have yet to make much of an impact on American emissions. For the record. the Paris agreement is just the first step needed to meet a 2 degree threshold. It really is only the first step up the ladder.

H8: History of the travel ban : look and see the law The Alien and Sedition Acts were signed into law by President John Adams in 1798 on the heels of the Quasi-War with France. The acts allowed the president to imprison or deport aliens considered "dangerous to the peace and safety of the United States" at any time and any male citizen of a hostile nation during times of war. Chinese Exclusion Laws Passed into law in 1882 by President Chester A. Arthur, this law prohibited the immigration of Chinese laborers. The Chinese Exclusion Act was a vital test for the power of the Federal Government to restrict immigration. It was upheld by the Supreme Court in the 1889 case of Chae Chan Ping v. United States. In the opinion of the court, Justice Stephen Johnson Field wrote, "The power of the government to exclude foreigners from the country whenever, in its judgment, the public interests require such exclusion, has been asserted in repeated instances, and never denied by the executive or legislative departments." The act was repealed by congress in 1943. Immigration Act Of 1917 Also known as the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, the Immigration Act of 1917 was passed by congress, who overrode a veto by President Woodrow Wilson, in 1917. In addition to barring, "homosexuals", "idiots", "feeble-minded persons", "criminals", "epileptics", "insane persons", alcoholics, "professional beggars", all persons "mentally or physically defective", polygamists, and anarchists, this act barred immigration from Southeast Asia, India, and the Middle East. Presidential Proclamations 2525, 2526, and 2527 These three proclamations were signed by president Franklin D. Roosevelt shortly after the attack on Pearl Harbor. Citing the Alien and Sedition Acts as precedence, these proclamations restricted the entry and naturalization of Japanese, Germans, and Italians respectively. The law : 1952 ‰ÛÏsection 212(f) of the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952.‰Û It says, ‰ÛÏWhenever the president finds that the entry of aliens or of any class of aliens into the United States would be detrimental to the interests of the United States, the president may, by proclamation, and for such period as he shall deem necessary, suspend the entry of all aliens or any class of aliens as immigrants or non-immigrant‰Ûªs or impose on the entry of aliens any restrictions he may deem to be appropriate.‰Û Former President George W.Bush used this authority six times as well during his tenure, typically on government officials. In January 2004, he signed an order ‰ÛÏbarring entry for public officials who solicit or accept bribes in exchange for any act or omission in their public duties that has serious adverse effects on the national interests of the U.S.; anyone who provides or offers to provide such a bribe; any current or former public official whose misappropriation of public funds or interference with public processes has had serious adverse effects on the national interests of the U.S.; or the immediate families.‰Û The groups Bush barred for entry included members of the Mugabe government in Zimbabwe and the Lukashenka government in Belarus. The authority of the president to bar certain classes of aliens was used six times by former President Bill Clinton. For example, in May of 1994 Clinton signed an order ‰ÛÏbarring entry for members of the Haitian military, their immediate families, any major participants in the coup d‰ÛªÌ©tat of 1991.‰Û Then in January of 1998, Clinton signed an order ‰ÛÏbarring entry for members of the military junta in Sierra Leone, and their families.‰Û Former President George H.W Bush only used this executive authority once in his four years of office. When he did use it, it was actually to undo a previous executive order by President Ronald Reagan that suspended entry of officers and employees of the Nicaraguan government. Former President Ronald Reagan used this executive authority five times while in office. In September of 1981, he barred the entry of ‰ÛÏany undocumented aliens arriving at the borders of the United States from the high seas.‰Û In August of 1986, Reagan signed an order ‰ÛÏbarring entry for any Cuban nationals or immigrants except in certain cases.‰Û These ‰ÛÏcertain cases‰Û included Cuban nationals who had applied for entry into the U.S as immediate family members and those who under law were ‰ÛÏspecial immigrants.‰Û Former President Jimmy Carter used this executive power only once and in a way quite similar to what Trump has proposed. In April 1980, as the U.S embassy in Tehran was under terrorist control, Carter signed an order invalidating ‰ÛÏall visas issued to Iranian citizens for future entry into the United States.‰Û The order said that the U.S ‰ÛÏwill not reissue visas, nor will we issue new visas, except for compelling and proven humanitarian reasons or where the national interest of our own country requires.‰Û Law Professor Jan Ting of Temple University told The Daily Caller that ‰ÛÏabsolutely and without any doubt‰Û does existing law allow Trump to restrict immigration of certain nationalities or religious groups. Tags: Barack Obama, Bill Clinton, Donald Trump, Elections 2016, George W. Bush, Jimmy Carter Below are Obama‰Ûªs actions: to stop immigrants ‰ÛÓ July 25, 2011. Barred those under a UN travel ban, or who broke 29 executive orders covering transactions with terrorists. ‰ÛÓ Aug. 4, 2012. Banned anybody involved in war crimes, or just about any other crime including human rights violations. ‰ÛÓ April 23, 2012. Barred those helping Syria or Iran, or involved in human rights abuses for those governments. ‰ÛÓ May 1, 2012. Another block on those helping Iran and Syria. ‰ÛÓ April 3, 2014. Article 2: 1 fight climate change through combating poverty, see item C. for monetary investment. See Article 3 for stipulation of aid to parties who lack resources. See Page 3, item 2 of Article 3 as follows for, contributions (monetary), and mitigation. See Page 3, Item 9 for monetary contribution every 5 years through Conference of parties based upon global stocktake of progressive action as defined in Article 7 Item 14. In short, the US will have unequal representation as a chief polluter while being held financially liable for said actions based upon real world factored demographics. Said contributions whether from liability or not, can be changed by offending party as mentioned in Item 11. In short, offending parties can negate financial liability. See item 16 for confederated nations joint actions as a singular party. See Article 6, Item 3, contributions are voluntary. See item 6 of Article 6 for administrative costs and rediverting administrative costs to fund developing countries. Clever wording that. See Item 9 of Article 6 for promoting non-market (party donation) aide. See item 7, of Article 7 for sharing information and technology, not mandatory. See Article 8, item 1 for guaranteed funding for WIMLD most likely through A6-6. Note, Article 8 has a lot of important legal information regarding the authority of WIMLD including the note on A8-4-g negating financial liability non-economic losses. Article 9-1, donation of funds to develop clean industry for underdeveloped parties, mandatory. Article 9-2 voluntary donations from other parties for the above purpose. Note, Article 9 does not explain scaled-up financial resources for Parties in Item 4, how to organize climate funds though potential sources are listed, some of which contradicting A9-6. Article 9-8, note who controls the collective donations to the Accords. Article 9-9, interesting preferential treatment for underdeveloped countries in regards to monetary aide. Article 10, a lot of interesting stuff here about sharing technology. No mention of whether shared information will violate domestic patents. Article 11, capacity development to development countries to combat greenhouse gases. Article 12, Parties take action to educate their respective publics on climate change. Note, no exact stipulations are put into place to determine proper education of source materials. There-go, countries can opt out with minimal endorsement. Article 13, regarads transparency of shared information between Parties. Item 10 of A-13 is of important note. It requires that both parties disclose the shared technologies. Should patients be illegally infringed upon it would be revealed here, yet in A-13-13 the parties assembled during conference reserve the right to adopt rights for tech transfers as deemed necessary. In short, they may be able to violate patent law without patent owner consent. Article 15-1, facilitate implementation, yet none of Article 15 elaborates upon compliance. Most of Article 16 deals with representation, rights, and operations of Parties during Convention. Article 20, stipulations for altering the accords through ratification. Article 24, settlement of disputes to this agreement. Note, no stipulations were made to sanctions.

J2: Heres what concerns me; the immediate focus is on the shooter, his politics, his social media posts and tweets. What about the ease of obtaining a gun; it seems the focus is on the swift response of guns that ended the conflict; and Im not saying thats isnt good; what I am saying is that we do need to add a discussion about guns to the nightmare of gun deaths in America. As sure as I say this the Second Amendment absolutist advocates will shout me down. The response to any suggestion of a discussion about guns is that the Constitution absolutely protects gun ownership; many argue that not even folks on the "no fly list" apparently can be deprived of a gun. But getting back to the shooters social media posts; the First amendment absolutely protects his "free speech" and certainly a claim that the actions of another constitutes treason is a protected free speech, right. So what relevance is there to even bring up his free speech posts. Will the Nation move towards restricting protected free speech in derogation of that absolutely protected Constitutional right of free speech; and, if so, does that not also open the door to an examination of the scope of the rights of gun owners. It seems to me we need to examine both the First and Second Amendments to reach a reasonable balance. We already have a ban on "hate speech." But what controls do we have on responsible gun ownership; even to raise the subject brings out the full force of the NRA in opposition to such a discussion. We even have laws prohibiting government funded studies of gun issues. WHEN WILL THE NATION HAVE THE COURAGE TO DISCUSS GUNS. This incident wont bring on any real discussion or result in any changes; why would it; the shooting and attempted assassination of Gabby Giffords in 2011, a member of the US House of Representatives from Arizona, ratcheted up the noise on guns but ultimately resulted in no change. And how long after the attempted assassination of President Reagan before passage of the Brady Bill? Not until 1994 was the bill passed. It was introduced by a democrat, Senator Charles (Chuck) Schumer), democrat, New York and signed by President Bill Clinton. The Brady Bill was in direct response to the attempted assassination of President Reagan and the incidental shooting of James Brady who suffered a serious head injury. That shooting occurred in March 1981 by a deranged John Hinkley who was trying to impress a well know actress. Twelve years of Republican control of the White House passed, it was not until the election of Bill Clinton that the Brady Bill finally made it into the law of the land. Does this tell us anything at all? The attempted assassination of President Reagan, the most hailed President by Republicans in the last 50 years, could not generate a reaction to gun violence. Not until a democratic administration almost 14 years later did the Brady Bill become law. Does this tell us anything? CAN WE HAVE THE FULL DISCUSSION ON GUNS AND FREE SPEECH THAT WE NEED TO HAVE. This is a long comment that very few will likely read, but if one person reads and agrees with me, it was worth the effort. It was worth the effort for me just to vent my frustration with the gun violence we all must endure. WHY, WHY, WHY.
